Hi SpaceX and Fans. I have watched all the test carried out on Star Ships including vessel pressure tests and flight tests. So far, vessels have proven their pressure capacity and I must say Congrats to the team for being persistent enough to cross that hurdle. Another significant hurdle that was crossed successfully was the belly flop maneuver and and descent control, again, Congrats to the team. However the team is yet to cross a next major hurdle of landing. From my observation of all landings so far, I noticed one thing in common and that is the angle of the vessel at the final descent stage before touch down. This is likely due to the angle / position of the engine carrying out the landing burn in relation to the center of gravity / mass, despite is ability to gimble. As a result of such, the landings achieved with SN 5, 6 and now 10 has left these vessels standing with a tilt, as the crushing forces was biased to one set of legs on impact. So it might be safe to say that, just changing the landing legs my not provide spectacular landings as with the Falcon boosters. The key thing is to work with the center of mass which is what enables the success of the F9 boosters. This may require a fourth engine to be placed at the center of mass to handle the final descent burn and a balance balanced approach at 90 degrees to the landing pad. It them appear that the legs are gonna have to housed in secured pockets covered with heat shield for re-entry and then ejected for landing. ''Keep It Simple''

Everything went well, but they need to be able to flush the engine area with something that will deny a fire, and thus explosion.  As a retired firefighter/EMT, a fire requires 4 parts to light, continue, and then explode - fuel, air, heat source, and a catalyst.  Upon landing, they could flush with an extreme coolant, to remove the heat source - presuming the raptors are all powered down.  I would think this would be the easiest, cheapest, most effective, etc.  The other huge benefit of cooling, is one could also effectively bring temps below the explosive range for the fuels in question; thus attacking from two directions with one application.  peace

Post landing Pad fire prevention or fighting...

After engines are shut down after landing, Starships may always have a bit of flaming fire from residual unburned fuel up under the rear skirt and engine bay.

It may be difficult to determine the difference between ‘normal’ residual flames and what might be a more serious fuel fed fire.

So.....

Equip landing pad with one or more remote controlled crawlers that would immediately scoot to where Starship comes to rest after each and every landing.

They would slide or stick a probe under the rear skirt and inject a large quantity of halon, CO2 or similar fire suppressant, into engine bay to extinguish any fires or burning parts.

Crawlers might have tanks on board, drag hoses behind or ability to exchange or refill charge ‘roomba’ style.

Crawlers also have video link and several cameras, along with fuel/gas detectors.

Similar crawlers might greet every landing to position powerful fans to force ventilate engine bay after flames are extinguished.
